steps.text@en: You are a young, energetic assistant at the city hall of a large European city. To advance in your career, you will have to make choices. Be careful.

choices.text@en: Go

steps.text@en: You issued a public tender for a new road segment, which you estimated at 10 million. Which offer do you pick?
steps.explainer@en:
How to spot a cartel?

Cartels appear when contractors get together to bid at the same price. You can spot it when the prices of the offers to a public tender are close to one another.

choices.text@en: Public Works plc. made an offer at 9 million
City Construction Limited made an offer at 20 million
Public Building plc made an offer at 21 million

steps.text@en: The boss of City Construction Limited wants to thank you personnally and gives you a brand new car, which he doesn't need. Do you accept it?

choices.text@en: Sure
No, thank you

steps.text@en: More and more people come to you for a house in social housing. What can you do?
steps.explainer@en:
Bribery in Europe

Bribery is uncommon in Europe, except for social housing. Read more at Cooking Budgets.

choices.text@en: Offer to speed their requests in exchange for $5000 in an envoleppe
Increase funding to the social housing program
Ignore them

steps.text@en: The head of the local football team, a friend of the mayor, wants a new training center. City hall has a nice piece of real estate that you value at 10 million.
steps.explainer@en:
Underselling real estate

Cities often sell plots of land much less than market prices to friendly buyers.

choices.text@en: Sell for 10 million
Sell for 4 million

steps.text@en: You issued a public tender for a new roundabout, which you estimated at 5 million. Which offer do you pick?
steps.explainer@en:
Cartels

It's very hard for a public works company to resist the pressure to join a cartel. Few can withstand it.

choices.text@en: Public Works plc. made an offer for 10 million
City Construction Limited made an offer for 10.2 million
Public Building plc made an offer for 11 million

steps.text@en: Would you like to create your own public works company?
steps.explainer@en:
Conflicts of interest

People in politics or in the administration can own companies that receive public contracts.

choices.text@en: Yes
No

steps.text@en: Who should be the nominal owner of the company?
steps.explainer@en:
Conflicts of interest

People in politics or in the administration can own companies that receive public contracts.

choices.text@en: You personnally
Your spouse or partner
A shell company in a tax heaven

steps.text@en: You issued a public tender for a new school, which you estimated at 3 million. Which offer do you pick?

choices.text@en: Your company made an offer for 5 million
Public Works plc. made an offer for 5.5 million
City Construction Limited made an offer for 6 million

steps.text@en: You issued a public tender for a new school, which you estimated at 3 million. Which offer do you pick?

choices.text@en: Public Building plc made an offer for 5 million
Public Works plc. made an offer for 5.5 million
City Construction Limited made an offer for 6 million

steps.text@en: Amazon has just arrived in town! You happen to have access to the credit card of your department.

choices.text@en: Buy lots of stuff online!
Do nothing

steps.text@en: It's election year. The mayor would like you to buy advertising for her campaign using city funds.

choices.text@en: No way, it's unethical
Sure, you'll run ads praising her actions

steps.text@en: The football club is in trouble. They need 12 million in cash. Would you accept to buy back the plot of land you sold them, and rent it back at a cheap price?

choices.text@en: Sure, a healthy football club for a healthy city!
No way, football clubs are private companies, they don't need a bail out.

steps.text@en: The boss of Public Works plc. asks you to pass a public tender of 100,000 to repair a road that doesn't exist. He offers to split the money 50/50.

choices.text@en: Accept
Decline

steps.text@en: You hear that someone at the bus company, owned by the city, keeps some of the cash clients pay.

choices.text@en: Offer him protection in exchange for a split of the money.
Report him to the police.
Do nothing.

steps.text@en: The mayor wants to build a new stadium for the local football team.

choices.text@en: The city should build one (one-off cost: 10 million).
Let's do a public-private partnership (no cost now, but you have to pay the contractor 1 million per year for the next 20 years)

steps.text@en: You hear that trash collection will soon be deregulated.

choices.text@en: Set up a trash collection company.
Do nothing.

steps.text@en: Trash collection must now be externalized. You do not know how much it cost the city because you did not do proper analysis. Which company do you pick?

choices.text@en: Your company made an offer at 1 million per year
Voelia Environment made an offer at 900,000 per year

steps.text@en: Trash collection must now be externalized. You do not know how much it cost the city because you did not do proper analysis. Which company do you pick?

choices.text@en: SATI Waste Management made an offer at 1.2 million per year
Voelia Environment made an offer at 900,000 per year

steps.text@en: The contractor for the new stadium is behind schedule. They do not want to pay the late penalty fee of 2 million.

choices.text@en: Take the contractor to court to get the money.
Ignore the delay.

steps.text@en: A friend of yours, dean of the city university, tells you over dinner in an expensive restaurant that he runs a scheme where students can pay $1,000 to obtain their degrees.

choices.text@en: Call the police.
choices.feedback@en: The police starts an investigation and you become 'the friend of the corrupt university professor'.

choices.text@en: Let him pick up the bill.

steps.text@en: An accountant just had an idea: Instead of accounting for the revenues of social housing every year, the city could account at once for the revenues of the next 20 years. This will artificially increase the city reserves, but reduce future resources.

choices.text@en: Accept! The appearance of wealth is better than nothing.
Refuse! Accounting should not be fiddled with.

steps.text@en: You spouse just got fired.

choices.text@en: Hire him as an assistant.
Ask City Construction Limited to hire him.
You should not mix private and professonal life.

steps.text@en: The boss of City Construction Limited invites you for a holiday in their chalet in Switzerland to discuss a possible job opportunity for you, as the boss of a new subsidiary they want to create.

choices.text@en: Accept the invitation.
choices.feedback@en: How sweet can life be in Switzerland! As an aside, the boss of City Construction Limited tells you they'd love to build a new swimming pool in your town.

choices.text@en: Decline.

steps.text@en: You pass a public tender for a new swimming pool (estimated cost: 1 million). Which offer do you pick?

choices.text@en: City Construction Limited made an offer at 10 million.
Choose not to award the tender.

steps.text@en: You pass a public tender for the rehabilitation of a city park (estimated cost: 500,000). Which offer do you pick?

choices.text@en: You company made an offer at 1 million.
City Construction Limited made an offer at 1.2 million.
Public Building plc made an offer at 1.3 million.

endings.text@en:
You're fired!

Your choices have made you unpopular. The mayor requests a career change for you. You're now in charge of welcoming guests at the city museum. How culturally enriching!

Busted!

The anticorruption police charged you with misapropriation of public funds. Relax, you probably won't go to prison, but the mayor demands that you resign.

Career change!

Public work contractors told the mayor's office that they could not work with you. You are being reassigned to the Parks and Gardens department. How great that you can work outside now!

New career

City Construction Limited makes you an offer you can't refuse, if only to ensure the financial well-being of your spouse and children. Bye-bye, public sector! Hello, business!

Celebrating 20 years

How time flies! 20 years already! In just another 20, you can be in retirement.
